title: IELTS Listening Test 01
content: Complete IELTS Listening Test 1 with all 4 sections (40 questions)

questions.instructions:
Questions 1-5: Complete the notes below. Write NO MORE THAN TWO WORDS AND/OR A NUMBER for each answer.

Community Courses for New Migrants
questions.question:
The woman arrived in the country [field 1] ago.

The Settlement Support Programme lasts for [field 2] weeks.

Students need to attend the Settlement Support Programme [field 3] days a week.

The discounted price for the handbook is [field 4].

Mentoring Programme sessions last for [field 5] each.
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is: 2 months. Make sure to listen carefully for key information and take notes while listening.

field_answers.5: one hour|1 hour|an hour|one-hour|1-hour|one hr|1 hr|60 minutes|60m

1.correct: Correct! The woman states she arrived in the country two months ago.
1.incorrect: Incorrect. Listen carefully to when the woman says she arrived in the country (Question 1).
1.no_answer: The correct answer is: 2 months. Make sure to listen carefully for key information and take notes while listening.

2.correct: Correct! The woman states she arrived in the country two months ago.
2.incorrect: Incorrect. Listen carefully to when the woman says she arrived in the country (Question 1).
2.no_answer: The correct answer is: 2 months. Make sure to listen carefully for key information and take notes while listening.

3.correct: Correct! The woman states she arrived in the country two months ago.
3.incorrect: Incorrect. Listen carefully to when the woman says she arrived in the country (Question 1).
3.no_answer: The correct answer is: 2 months. Make sure to listen carefully for key information and take notes while listening.

4.correct: Correct! The woman states she arrived in the country two months ago.
4.incorrect: Incorrect. Listen carefully to when the woman says she arrived in the country (Question 1).
4.no_answer: The correct answer is: 2 months. Make sure to listen carefully for key information and take notes while listening.

5.correct: Correct! The woman states she arrived in the country two months ago.
5.incorrect: Incorrect. Listen carefully to when the woman says she arrived in the country (Question 1).
5.no_answer: The correct answer is: 2 months. Make sure to listen carefully for key information and take notes while listening.

questions.instructions:
Questions 6-10: Multiple Choice
Choose the correct answer (A, B, or C).
questions.question: How many mentors are currently on the team?
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is B. 15. The operator states there are currently 15 mentors on the team. In the IELTS test, you should always take a guess. You don't lose points for a wrong answer.

mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. 4 is the number of clients each mentor sees per week, not total mentors.
Correct! The operator states there are currently 15 mentors total.
Incorrect. This number is not mentioned in relation to mentors at all.

questions.question: How many clients does each mentor see per week?
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is B. 4. Each mentor sees 4 clients per week according to the details provided in the conversation. In the IELTS test, you should always take a guess. You don't lose points for a wrong answer.

mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. There are 2 sessions per week, but each mentor sees 4 clients (not 2) in total weekly.
Correct! Each mentor sees 4 clients per week, according to details.
Incorrect. This number is not mentioned in the conversation.

questions.question: When is the next available Settlement Support Programme course?
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is B. 3rd October. Although there's a course on 26th September, it's already fully booked, so the next available course is 3rd October. In the IELTS test, you should always take a guess. You don't lose points for a wrong answer.

mc_options.text: A. 26th September
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. This course starts on 26th September but is already fully booked/not available.

mc_options.text: B. 3rd October
mc_options.feedback: Correct! Although there's a course on 26th September, it's full. The next available is 3rd October.

mc_options.text: C. 10th October
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. This date is not mentioned at all in the conversation.

questions.options:
A. 26th September
B. 3rd October
C. 10th October

questions.question: Where is the office located?
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is A. On the 2nd floor of Lakeside View building. The operator clearly states the office is on the 2nd floor of the Lakeside View building on St James Plaza. In the IELTS test, you should always take a guess. You don't lose points for a wrong answer.

mc_options.text: A. On the 2nd floor of Lakeside View building
mc_options.feedback: Correct! The operator states the office is on the 2nd floor of the Lakeside View building.

mc_options.text: B. On St James Plaza
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. The building is on St James Plaza (not Street), but this doesn't specify the floor or building name.

mc_options.text: C. Next to the public car park
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. The car park is next to the building, but this doesn't describe the office itself.

questions.options:
A. On the 2nd floor of Lakeside View building
B. On St James Plaza
C. Next to the public car park

questions.question: Which car park should students not use?
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is B. The staff car park at the front. The operator clearly warns not to use the car park at the front as it's reserved for staff only. In the IELTS test, you should always take a guess. You don't lose points for a wrong answer.

mc_options.text: A. The public car park on the left
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. Students are actually encouraged to use the public car park on the left - it's recommended.

mc_options.text: B. The staff car park at the front
mc_options.feedback: Correct! The operator clearly warns not to use the car park at the front as it's reserved for staff.

mc_options.text: C. The one behind the building
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. A car park behind the building is not mentioned in the conversation.

questions.options:
A. The public car park on the left
B. The staff car park at the front
C. The one behind the building

questions.instructions: Questions 11-14: Complete the sentences below. Write NO MORE THAN THREE WORDS.
questions.question:
Gorgona Island housed a maximum security prison until [field 1].

The island is also known as Science Island because of the [field 2] the coral environment presents.

White-sand beaches are located on the [field 3] of Gorgona Island.

The vegetation around the prison buildings provides a [field 4] for wildlife observation.

1. [Field 1]

2. [Field 2]

3. [Field 3]

4. [Field 4]
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is: 1985. Make sure to listen carefully for key information and take notes while listening.

1.correct: Correct! The prison was operational until 1985 when it was closed and the island became a natural park.
1.incorrect: Incorrect. Listen for the year when the prison was closed. The speaker mentions when Gorgona Island was declared a natural park.
1.no_answer: The correct answer is: 1985. Make sure to listen carefully for key information and take notes while listening.

2.correct: Correct! The prison was operational until 1985 when it was closed and the island became a natural park.
2.incorrect: Incorrect. Listen for the year when the prison was closed. The speaker mentions when Gorgona Island was declared a natural park.
2.no_answer: The correct answer is: 1985. Make sure to listen carefully for key information and take notes while listening.

3.correct: Correct! The prison was operational until 1985 when it was closed and the island became a natural park.
3.incorrect: Incorrect. Listen for the year when the prison was closed. The speaker mentions when Gorgona Island was declared a natural park.
3.no_answer: The correct answer is: 1985. Make sure to listen carefully for key information and take notes while listening.

4.correct: Correct! The prison was operational until 1985 when it was closed and the island became a natural park.
4.incorrect: Incorrect. Listen for the year when the prison was closed. The speaker mentions when Gorgona Island was declared a natural park.
4.no_answer: The correct answer is: 1985. Make sure to listen carefully for key information and take notes while listening.

questions.instructions:
Questions 15-16: Choose TWO letters A-E.

What TWO rules must visitors to Gorgona Island obey? Visitors must...
questions.question:
A. stay on jungle trails
B. not take prohibited items to the island
C. take all rubbish away with them
D. meet medical requirements
E. carry a first aid kit
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answers are B and D. Visitors must not take prohibited items to the island (such as electrical appliances, alcoholic beverages, sprays and contaminants, arms, and articles for hunting or capturing animals), and they must meet medical requirements (getting vaccinated against yellow fever, tetanus, and hepatitis B at least 10 days before arriving). In the IELTS test, you should always take a guess. You don't lose points for a wrong answer.

mc_options.text: A. stay on jungle trails
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. While visitors are supervised and limited in where they can go (not too far from the coastline), staying on jungle trails specifically is not mentioned as a requirement.

mc_options.text: B. not take prohibited items to the island
mc_options.feedback: Correct! Visitors are prohibited from bringing electrical appliances, alcoholic beverages, sprays and contaminants, arms, and articles for hunting or capturing animals to the island.

mc_options.text: C. take all rubbish away with them
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. The recording states that no non-biodegradable rubbish must be left behind and organic waste should be placed in special containers for collection by rangers, not taken away.

mc_options.text: D. meet medical requirements
mc_options.feedback: Correct! Visitors are required to get vaccinated against yellow fever, tetanus, and hepatitis B at least 10 days before arriving, and must show vaccination certificates.

mc_options.text: E. carry a first aid kit
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. While visitors are strongly recommended to take a first aid kit with snake anti-venom and medicine, it is not compulsory.

questions.options:
A. stay on jungle trails
B. not take prohibited items to the island
C. take all rubbish away with them
D. meet medical requirements
E. carry a first aid kit

questions.instructions:
Questions 17-20: Choose the correct letter A, B or C.

17. On Gorgona Island there are.....
questions.question: On Gorgona Island there are.....
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is C. more types of marine species than insects. The recording states there are over 100 insect species but more than 500 species of marine fauna on Gorgona Island. In the IELTS test, you should always take a guess. You don't lose points for a wrong answer.

mc_options.text: A. more types of insects than birds
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. There are 147 bird species and over 100 insect species, so there are more bird species.

mc_options.text: B. more types of birds than marine animals
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. There are 147 bird species but more than 500 species of marine fauna, so there are more marine species.

mc_options.text: C. more types of marine species than insects
mc_options.feedback: Correct! The recording states there are over 100 insect species but more than 500 species of marine fauna on Gorgona Island.

questions.options:
A. more types of insects than birds
B. more types of birds than marine animals
C. more types of marine species than insects

questions.question: Humpback whales.....
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is B. can reliably be seen during mating season. The recording states that with more than 1000 humpback whales arriving during mating and calving season, tourists need not be concerned their whale-watching trip will be unsuccessful. In the IELTS test, you should always take a guess. You don't lose points for a wrong answer.

mc_options.text: A. travel from the Pacific Coast to give birth
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. The whales travel TO the Pacific Coast (specifically to Colombian waters) to give birth, not from it. They travel 8000km from the poles.

mc_options.text: B. can reliably be seen during mating season
mc_options.feedback: Correct! The recording states that with more than 1000 humpback whales arriving during mating and calving season, tourists need not be concerned their whale-watching trip will be unsuccessful.

mc_options.text: C. migrate at the beginning of the year
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. Humpback whales migrate between June and October each year, not at the beginning of the year.

questions.options:
A. travel from the Pacific Coast to give birth
B. can reliably be seen during mating season
C. migrate at the beginning of the year

questions.question: The boat ride from Buenaventura to Gorgona Island takes....
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is B. 12 hours. The recording clearly states that the boat ride from Buenaventura takes 12 hours. In the IELTS test, you should always take a guess. You don't lose points for a wrong answer.

mc_options.text: A. 10 hours
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. 10 hours is mentioned but it's the travel time from Buenaventura to Bogota by road, not the boat ride to Gorgona Island.

mc_options.text: B. 12 hours
mc_options.feedback: Correct! The recording clearly states that the boat ride from Buenaventura takes 12 hours.

mc_options.text: C. 1 hour 40 minutes
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. 1 hour 40 minutes is the boat ride time from Guapi to Gorgona Island, not from Buenaventura.

questions.options:
A. 10 hours
B. 12 hours
C. 1 hour 40 minutes

questions.question: The cost of trips to Gorgona Island increased when....
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is C. one tourism operator was given control. In 2009, the government decided to give a private company sole control over all tourism on Gorgona Island, which resulted in exponential price increases. In the IELTS test, you should always take a guess. You don't lose points for a wrong answer.

mc_options.text: A. the Government took control of tourism there
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. The government didn't take control themselves; rather, they gave control to a private company. It was this privatization, not government control, that increased prices.

mc_options.text: B. prison guard quarters were refurbished for accommodation
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. While the prison guard quarters were remodelled into bungalows, this happened as part of the overall tourism changes, not as the cause of the price increase.

mc_options.text: C. one tourism operator was given control
mc_options.feedback: Correct! In 2009, the government decided to give a private company sole control over all tourism on Gorgona Island, which resulted in exponential price increases.

questions.options:
A. the Government took control of tourism there
B. prison guard quarters were refurbished for accommodation
C. one tourism operator was given control

questions.instructions:
Questions 21-25: Answer the following questions using NO MORE THAN THREE WORDS AND/OR A NUMBER.

Changes in New Zealand Family Structures
questions.question:
21. A divorce rate of slightly below what has been recorded for couples who married in 1970 in New Zealand?
[field 1] 22. Types of family and what have been changing since the 1960s?
[field 2]

What has dropped significantly since the 1960s? [field 3]

What type of household was at 23% in 2006 and is expected to reach 26% in 2021? [field 4]

What percentage of households do not have children? [field 5]
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is: one third. Make sure to listen carefully for key information and take notes while listening.

field_answers.4: Single person|Single parent family|Single persons|Single-person|single person household|single person households
field_answers.5: Around 20%|20|Twenty|20%|twenty %|20 per cent|twenty per cent|twenty percent|20 percent|around 20|around twenty|around 20%|around twenty %|around 20 per cent|around twenty per cent|around twenty percent|around 20 percent

1.correct: Correct! Just under one third of couples who married in 1970 had divorced by their jade wedding anniversary.
1.incorrect: Incorrect. Listen for the divorce rate mentioned for couples who married in 1970 (Q21).
1.no_answer: The correct answer is: one third. Make sure to listen carefully for key information and take notes while listening.

2.correct: Correct! Just under one third of couples who married in 1970 had divorced by their jade wedding anniversary.
2.incorrect: Incorrect. Listen for the divorce rate mentioned for couples who married in 1970 (Q21).
2.no_answer: The correct answer is: one third. Make sure to listen carefully for key information and take notes while listening.

3.correct: Correct! Just under one third of couples who married in 1970 had divorced by their jade wedding anniversary.
3.incorrect: Incorrect. Listen for the divorce rate mentioned for couples who married in 1970 (Q21).
3.no_answer: The correct answer is: one third. Make sure to listen carefully for key information and take notes while listening.

4.correct: Correct! Just under one third of couples who married in 1970 had divorced by their jade wedding anniversary.
4.incorrect: Incorrect. Listen for the divorce rate mentioned for couples who married in 1970 (Q21).
4.no_answer: The correct answer is: one third. Make sure to listen carefully for key information and take notes while listening.

5.correct: Correct! Just under one third of couples who married in 1970 had divorced by their jade wedding anniversary.
5.incorrect: Incorrect. Listen for the divorce rate mentioned for couples who married in 1970 (Q21).
5.no_answer: The correct answer is: one third. Make sure to listen carefully for key information and take notes while listening.

questions.instructions:
Questions 26-27: Choose the correct letter A, B or C.

26. Some people are having families later.....
questions.question: Some people are having families later.....
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is B. So they can gain other life experiences first. Speaker 1 says younger people appreciate a few years of freedom with no family commitments and mentions mobility, work and travel experiences that are difficult with children. In the IELTS test, you should always take a guess. You don't lose points for a wrong answer.

mc_options.text: A. So they can finish their university education
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. University education is not mentioned as a reason for delaying parenthood in the conversation.

mc_options.text: B. So they can gain other life experiences first
mc_options.feedback: Correct! Speaker 1 says younger people appreciate a few years of freedom with no family commitments and mentions mobility, work and travel experiences that are difficult with children.

mc_options.text: C. So that they are more mature when they have children
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. Maturity is not mentioned as a reason for delaying having children in the conversation.

questions.options:
A. So they can finish their university education
B. So they can gain other life experiences first
C. So that they are more mature when they have children

questions.question: Increasing numbers of older people are currently living in retirement homes because.....
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is C. Their families live in different places. Speaker 2 states that families are spread geographically or children work so much they aren't able to give elderly parents the time they need. In the IELTS test, you should always take a guess. You don't lose points for a wrong answer.

mc_options.text: A. Their children don't want to look after them
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. It's not that children don't want to look after them, but rather that they are unable to due to geography or work commitments.

mc_options.text: B. They receive better health care
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. Better health care is not mentioned as a reason in the conversation.

mc_options.text: C. Their families live in different places
mc_options.feedback: Correct! Speaker 2 states that families are spread geographically or children work so much they aren't able to give elderly parents the time they need.

questions.options:
A. Their children don't want to look after them
B. They receive better health care
C. Their families live in different places

questions.instructions:
Questions 28-30: List the THREE methods of communication that the speaker says negatively affect community feeling.

Write NO MORE THAN TWO WORDS for each answer
questions.question:
28. [field 1]

29. [field 2]

30. [field 3]

1. [Field 1]

2. [Field 2]

3. [Field 3]
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answers are: texts (or text messages), email (or e-mail), and social media. Make sure to listen carefully for key information and take notes while listening.

field_answers.1: texts|text|email|e mail|e-mail|emails|e mails|e-mails|social media|text messages|text message|texting
field_answers.2: texts|text|email|e mail|e-mail|emails|e mails|e-mails|social media|text messages|text message|texting
field_answers.3: texts|text|email|e mail|e-mail|emails|e mails|e-mails|social media|text messages|text message|texting

1.correct: Correct! Speaker 1 mentions that people are using texts, email and social media rather than talking, which affects community feeling.
1.incorrect: Incorrect. Listen for the three methods of communication Speaker 1 says negatively affect the feeling of community (Q28-30).
1.no_answer: The correct answers are: texts (or text messages), email (or e-mail), and social media. Speaker 1 mentions these three methods of communication negatively affect the feeling of community.

2.correct: Correct! Speaker 1 mentions that people are using texts, email and social media rather than talking, which affects community feeling.
2.incorrect: Incorrect. Listen for the three methods of communication Speaker 1 says negatively affect the feeling of community (Q28-30).
2.no_answer: The correct answers are: texts (or text messages), email (or e-mail), and social media. Speaker 1 mentions these three methods of communication negatively affect the feeling of community.

3.correct: Correct! Speaker 1 mentions that people are using texts, email and social media rather than talking, which affects community feeling.
3.incorrect: Incorrect. Listen for the three methods of communication Speaker 1 says negatively affect the feeling of community (Q28-30).
3.no_answer: The correct answers are: texts (or text messages), email (or e-mail), and social media. Speaker 1 mentions these three methods of communication negatively affect the feeling of community.

questions.instructions:
Questions 31-34: Complete the sentences below. Use NO MORE THAN TWO WORDS AND/OR A NUMBER for each answer.

Factors Affecting Elections
questions.question:
General elections in the UK are not held on [field 1] but must be held within 5 years.

Voter turnout is the percentage of [field 2] voters who vote in an election.

Voter turnout is usually just over 80% in [field 3].

Voter turnout is getting lower in the United States, Western Europe, Japan and [field 4].

1. [Field 1]

2. [Field 2]

3. [Field 3]

4. [Field 4]
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is: FIXED DATES. Make sure to listen carefully for key information and take notes while listening.

field_answers.1: FIXED DATES|A FIXED DATE|FIXED DATE|fixed dates|a fixed date|fixed date
field_answers.3: AUSTRALIA|Australia|81%|81 %|81 percent|81 per cent|eighty one percent|eighty one per cent

1.correct: Correct! General elections in the UK do not have fixed dates, though they must be held every five years.
1.incorrect: Incorrect. Listen for what General elections in the UK do not have, unlike other types of elections.
1.no_answer: The correct answer is: FIXED DATES. Make sure to listen carefully for key information and take notes while listening.

2.correct: Correct! General elections in the UK do not have fixed dates, though they must be held every five years.
2.incorrect: Incorrect. Listen for what General elections in the UK do not have, unlike other types of elections.
2.no_answer: The correct answer is: FIXED DATES. Make sure to listen carefully for key information and take notes while listening.

3.correct: Correct! General elections in the UK do not have fixed dates, though they must be held every five years.
3.incorrect: Incorrect. Listen for what General elections in the UK do not have, unlike other types of elections.
3.no_answer: The correct answer is: FIXED DATES. Make sure to listen carefully for key information and take notes while listening.

4.correct: Correct! General elections in the UK do not have fixed dates, though they must be held every five years.
4.incorrect: Incorrect. Listen for what General elections in the UK do not have, unlike other types of elections.
4.no_answer: The correct answer is: FIXED DATES. Make sure to listen carefully for key information and take notes while listening.

questions.instructions:
Questions 35-36: Choose TWO letters A-E.

Which of the following socioeconomic factors affect voting habits?
questions.question:
A. Ethnicity
B. Wealth
C. Occupation
D. Marital status
E. Religion
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answers are B and D. Wealth (income) is mentioned as having an independent effect - richer people are more likely to vote than poor people. Marital status is also a factor - the lecture states that single people are less likely to vote than married people. In the IELTS test, you should always take a guess. You don't lose points for a wrong answer.

mc_options.text: A. Ethnicity
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. Ethnicity is not mentioned as a socioeconomic factor affecting voting habits in the lecture (Q35-36).

mc_options.text: B. Wealth
mc_options.feedback: Correct! Income (wealth) is mentioned as having an independent effect - richer people are more likely to vote than poor people (Q35 or Q36).

mc_options.text: C. Occupation
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. Occupation is not mentioned as a socioeconomic factor affecting voting habits in the lecture.

mc_options.text: D. Marital status
mc_options.feedback: Correct! The lecture states that single people are less likely to vote than married people, making marital status a factor (Q35 or Q36).

mc_options.text: E. Religion
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. Religion is not mentioned as a socioeconomic factor affecting voting habits in the lecture.

questions.options:
A. Ethnicity
B. Wealth
C. Occupation
D. Marital status
E. Religion

questions.instructions:
Questions 37-40: Complete the table below. Write NO MORE THAN THREE WORDS for each answer.

Voter Apathy
questions.question:
Candidates can inspire [field 1] (Q37).

Outcome seems inevitable and / or election topics are not of [field 2] to voters (Q38).

[field 3] and /or complicated voting processes reduces turnout (Q39).

Ballot papers are too complicated and require voters to have too much patience and / or [field 4] (Q40).

1. [Field 1]

2. [Field 2]

3. [Field 3]

4. [Field 4]
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answers are: Q37: CONFIDENCE, Q38: personal importance (or importance), Q39: bad weather, Q40: knowledge. Make sure to listen carefully for key information and take notes while listening.

1.correct: Correct! Leaders and parties need to inspire confidence to decrease voter apathy and increase turnout (Q37).
1.incorrect: Incorrect. Listen for what leaders and parties should inspire to decrease voter apathy when discussing trust (Q37).
1.no_answer: The correct answer is: CONFIDENCE. Leaders and parties need to inspire confidence to decrease voter apathy and increase turnout.

2.correct: Correct! The perceived importance of issues in an election influences voter turnout - if the issues are not of personal importance to a voter, their apathy may be increased (Q38).
2.incorrect: Incorrect. Listen for what quality election topics need to have to be relevant to voters (Q38).
2.no_answer: The correct answer is: personal importance (or importance). If the issues in an election are not of personal importance to a voter, their apathy may be increased.

3.correct: Correct! Bad weather can reduce voter turnout as mentioned in the lecture (Q39).
3.incorrect: Incorrect. Listen for one of the practical issues that can affect voter turnout (Q39).
3.no_answer: The correct answer is: bad weather. Bad weather can reduce voter turnout as mentioned in the lecture.

4.correct: Correct! Ballot fatigue occurs when affected voters use up all their patience and/or their knowledge as they work their way down the ballot (Q40).
4.incorrect: Incorrect. Listen for what voters might run out of besides patience when experiencing ballot fatigue (Q40).
4.no_answer: The correct answer is: knowledge. Ballot fatigue occurs when affected voters use up all their patience and/or their knowledge as they work their way down the ballot.

audio.transcript:
<td valign="top" width="[Q25: 20]%">Telephone operator
Good morning. Eastville Council. How can I help you?
Woman Hello, I understand you offer a number of community classes to new migrants. I was wondering if it would be possible to enrol?
Telephone operator Yes we do. We run language classes of course, a settlement support programme and we also offer a new mentoring programme which we're actually trialling for [Q2: 3] months starting next week. Can I ask, are you a permanent resident?
Woman Yes I am.
Telephone operator That's no problem then, you must be a permanent resident to enrol in any of our courses, you see. So which course are you interested in?
Woman Well, I am interested in the settlement support programme and the Mentoring Programme, I am finding it difficult to get a job interview you see. I arrived in the country [Q1: two] months ago. My husband work full-time but I am looking for work too. Just a part-time job to start with as we have two young children. I'm not sure which course would suit me best. Could you give me some more information about those please?
Telephone operator Well the Settlement Support Programme is [Q2: three] weeks long and students need to attend class [Q3: 4] days a week. The focus is on settling into work in a new country, so we provide help with searching for jobs, enrolling with employment agencies, writing a CV and writing application letters.
Woman That does sound interesting. I think that would be a lot of use to me. Is the course completely free? Do I need to pay for textbooks or anything like that?
Telephone operator For the Settlement Support Programme, we do recommend that students buy a handbook which accompanies the course - it's not compulsory to buy but it only costs ₤10.99 if you buy direct from the bookstore so we do recommend that you purchase your own copy if you are able to. We can place a bulk order for the book at the beginning of the course and students only pay [Q4: ₤7].95 if they order early enough to qualify for the discount.
Woman Okay. And how about the Mentoring Programme? Could you tell me a little more about that please?
Telephone operator Well these are one to one sessions instead of a group class. They run for two weeks with two [Q5: one] hour sessions each week. The idea is that if you are having any specific difficulties settling in to your new life, be that work, or social issues, your mentor can talk with you and give suggestions and advice on how to make things better. We currently have [Q6: 15] mentors on the team and each will mentor [Q7: [Q3: four]] clients per week. The mentor programme is free but we suggest people join the Settlement Support Programme first then enrol on a Mentor Programme afterwards if they still feel in need of additional support.
Woman Okay I understand, thank you. So what do I need to do about enrolling on the Settlement Support Programme? I'd like to enrol as soon as I can.
Telephone operator Well, you will need to come into our office and fill out an application form. Make sure that you bring your passport with you to confirm your residency and we will also need two additional passport photographs; one for our records and one for your student ID card.
Woman Okay. I'll come in this afternoon. So when does the next course start?
Telephone operator The next course starts next Monday, on the 26th September, but that one is already fully booked. We have new courses starting each week, so the next with an available place is on the [Q8: 3rd] October.
Woman Okay. Well thanks very much for your help. It sounds like the Settlement Support Programme is ideal for me and I'll think later about whether to apply for Mentor Support. I'll come in very soon. Can you just remind me where the office is?
Telephone operator Yes we're on the [Q9: 2nd] floor of the Lakeside View building on St James Plaza. We are in the tall white building next to the technical college. We're very easy to find and there are plenty of places to park in the public car park just to the left of the building. Don't use the [Q10: car] park at the front though as those spaces are reserved for staff.
Woman That's great thank you very much for all your help. Looking forward to meeting you when I come in later today.
Telephone operator You're very welcome. Glad I could help.

sections.transcript:
Telephone Operator: Good morning. Eastville Council. How can I help you?

Woman: Hello, I understand you offer a number of community classes to new migrants. I was wondering if it would be possible to enrol?

Telephone Operator: Yes, we do. We run language classes of course, a settlement support programme, and we also offer a new mentoring programme which we're actually trialling for three months starting next week. Can I ask, are you a permanent resident?

Woman: Yes, I am.

Telephone Operator: That's no problem then. You must be a permanent resident to enrol in any of our courses, you see. So, which course are you interested in?

Woman: Well, I am interested in the settlement support programme and the mentoring programme. I am finding it difficult to get a job interview, you see. I arrived in the country two months ago. My husband works full-time, but I am looking for work too. Just a part-time job to start with as we have two young children. I'm not sure which course would suit me best. Could you give me some more information about those, please?

Telephone Operator: Well, the Settlement Support Programme is three weeks long, and students need to attend class four days a week. The focus is on settling into work in a new country, so we provide help with searching for jobs, enrolling with employment agencies, writing a CV, and writing application letters.

Woman: That does sound interesting. I think that would be a lot of use to me. Is the course completely free? Do I need to pay for textbooks or anything like that?

Telephone Operator: For the Settlement Support Programme, we do recommend that students buy a handbook that accompanies the course. It's not compulsory to buy, but it only costs ₤10.99 if you buy direct from the bookstore, so we do recommend that you purchase your own copy if you are able to. We can place a bulk order for the book at the beginning of the course, and students only pay ₤7.95 if they order early enough to qualify for the discount.

Woman: Okay. And how about the Mentoring Programme? Could you tell me a little more about that, please?

Telephone Operator: Well, these are one-to-one sessions instead of a group class. They run for two weeks with two one-hour sessions each week. The idea is that if you are having any specific difficulties settling into your new life, be that work or social issues, your mentor can talk with you and give suggestions and advice on how to make things better.

We currently have 15 mentors on the team, and each will mentor four clients per week. The mentor programme is free, but we suggest people join the Settlement Support Programme first, then enrol on a Mentoring Programme afterwards if they still feel in need of additional support.

Woman: Okay, I understand. Thank you. So, what do I need to do about enrolling on the Settlement Support Programme? I'd like to enrol as soon as I can.

Telephone Operator: Well, you will need to come into our office and fill out an application form. Make sure that you bring your passport with you to confirm your residency, and we will also need two additional passport photographs: one for our records and one for your student ID card.

Woman: Okay. I'll come in this afternoon. So, when does the next course start?

Telephone Operator: The next course starts next Monday, on the 26th September, but that one is already fully booked. We have new courses starting each week, so the next with an available place is on the 3rd October.

Woman: Okay. Well, thanks very much for your help. It sounds like the Settlement Support Programme is ideal for me, and I'll think later about whether to apply for Mentor Support. I'll come in very soon. Can you just remind me where the office is?

Telephone Operator: Yes, we're on the 2nd floor of the Lakeside View building on St James Plaza. We are in the tall white building next to the technical college. We're very easy to find, and there are plenty of places to park in the public car park just to the left of the building. Don't use the car park at the front though, as those spaces are reserved for staff.

Woman: That's great! Thank you very much for all your help. Looking forward to meeting you when I come in later today.

Telephone Operator: You're very welcome. Glad I could help.

Section 2 Once the home of a maximum security prison, Gorgona Island, a small 25 km² island in the Colombian Pacific, is now home to a natural paradise and has become an important centre for eco-tourism and fauna and flora [Q2: research]. From the 1950s and for around 30 years, this landmass in the Pacific was a maximum security prison —Colombia's Alcatraz some might say. The 56km of rough, shark-infested waters and its venomous snakes arguably making it the ideal place to house the most violent criminals of the time, as these hazards usually put an end to any hope of escape. The prison was operational until (11) [Q1: 1985] when the penal facility was closed and Gorgona Island was declared a natural national park by the Colombian Government, UNESCO having recognised the island a World Heritage Site in the previous year, 1984. Gorgona Island is known as the 'Science Island' due to its coral reef and tropical rainforest ecosystems and the (12) research possibilities they present. The island was originally discovered in 1524 by Diego de Almagro, who gave Gorgona Island its name due to the large number of reptiles and the association with the Gorgons from Greek mythology – 'woman-demons with the hair of snakes'. Gorgona Island is home to a wealth of native plant and animal species in its rainforests. On its (13) [Q3: eastern side], the island also boasts some of the finest white-sand beaches in Colombia, while the west coast is made up of cliffs. There are also several hills on the island, the tallest being La Trinidad which peaks at 388 meters. While the prison buildings remain, they are now overgrown with dense vegetation and provide a (14) [Q4: perfect environment] in which to observe all kinds of wildlife such as monkeys swinging through the vines. In order to preserve the environment, visitors who travel to Gorgona Island are strictly supervised, are limited to groups of 80 at a time, and are also prohibited from wandering too far away from the coastline. Especially during high season, it is advised that reservations are made one or two months in advance in order to avoid disappointment as visitor quotas are staunchly upheld and quickly filled. Tourists are required to strictly follow the rules of the Natural Park at all times to preserve the flora and fauna on the island. (15 or 16) Electrical appliances such as stoves and hair dryers, alcoholic beverages, sprays and other contaminants, arms, and articles for hunting or capturing animals are banned and must not be brought to the island. No non-biodegradable rubbish must be left behind. Any organic waste should be placed in special containers found in the park for collection by rangers. (15 or 16) Visitors are also required get vaccinated against yellow fever, tetanus, and hepatitis B at least 10 days before arriving on the island (vaccination certificates must be shown on entrance to the park). In the interests of their own safety, while not compulsory, visitors are also strongly recommended to take a first aid kit that includes multipurpose snake anti-venom and medicine for diarrhoea, along with rubber boots, a change of clothes, and sun block. Absolutely strictly forbidden is the collecting of shells, coral or other mineral material from the protected area and the taking of any seeds, plants or animals, all of which could have catastrophic effect on the island's ecosystem. The terrestrial animal population on Gorgona Island includes sloths, blue lizards, fresh water turtles, snakes, and babilla alligators. (17) There are 147 bird species, over 100 insect species, more than 500 species of marine fauna. There are also hundreds of species of marine and terrestrial plant life on Gorgona Island. The sea around Gorgona Island has the most developed and diverse coral bank in the Eastern Tropical Pacific Ocean, which is also the largest in the country's Pacific region. The island's surrounding waters provide tourists with a great opportunity to observe, amongst other species, dolphins, porpoises, sharks, sperm whales and humpback whales, the latter also known as the Yubarta whale. The Colombian Pacific coast is the mating and birthing area for the humpback whale, which migrates between June and October each year. Almost all humpback whales found in this region are born in Colombian waters and are faithful to their birthplace, travelling 8000Km from the poles to have their babies and feed them in the warmer waters of Gorgona Island. (18) With more than 1000 humpback whales arriving in Gorgona Island's waters during mating and calving season, tourists need not be concerned that their whale-watching trip will be unsuccessful, rather how just many of these majestic creatures they will be able to see. Relatively few people can boast of a trip to Gorgona Island. Not only are visitor numbers restricted, but the trip is also difficult and is becoming increasingly expensive. The boat ride from Buenaventura (a coastal city of more than 300,000 people situated about 10 hours from Bogota and four hours from Cali) takes (19) 12 hours. Alternatively it is an hour-and-40-minute boat ride from Guapi, an Afro-pacific town near the border of Ecuador, but no roads lead to Guapi. Guapi's single-runway Juan Casino Solis Airport does, however, service flights to and from the southern cities of Cali and Popyan. Until 2009, visitors could make day trips to Gorgona from Guapi or spend a night there for as little as US$12. However, in that same year the government decided to give (20) a private company sole control over all tourism on Gorgona Island which resulted in exponential price increases. Since then a park permit, night in a basic bungalow in the remodelled prison-guard quarters, three meals and a return boat ride from Guapi can cost at least US$250, and additional nights around US$150. All activities — whale watching, snorkelling, even walking around the island — are extra. While these prices may still be in the price range for overseas visitors, they are prohibitively expensive for many locals. The people who do make it to Gorgona, however, can rest assured that they will be left blissfully alone in extraordinarily wild surroundings, and know that since such small numbers visit the island, its incredible ecosystem can continue to flourish.

Section 3

Speaker 1 Did you see that programme on TV3 last night? The one about the traditional family and how family structures are changing in New Zealand?
Speaker 2 No – I was going to watch it but forgot it was on!
Speaker 1 Oh, you should have seen it. It was really interesting. It started by talking about the divorce rate and the myth that half of marriages end in divorce. Apparently there are approximately 10,000 divorces and 20,000 marriages in New Zealand each year. That causes people to think the divorce rate is 50%. In reality though, statistics show that just under [Q21: 1/3] of couples who married in 1970 had divorced by their jade wedding anniversary. Of those who married in 1980, just under 1/3 of couples had already divorced by their silver wedding anniversary. This is still well below one-half of all marriages though.
Speaker 2 Hmm. I think the divorce rate here is probably lower than a lot of other countries too. What else did they talk about?
Speaker 1 They were saying that since the 1960s there have been a lot of changes in types of family and [Q22: household structures] and that these continue to change. Two very significant trends since that time are that people are more likely to live with a partner before marrying now than in previous years, and [Q23: birth rates] are on the decrease. There has been an increase in single-parent families and an increase in blended families – when people who have been married and divorced meet a new partner and join their children to make a new family.
Speaker 2 Don't more people live by themselves these days too? I remember reading something about that in a newspaper.
Speaker 1 Yes, that's true. The programme said that [Q24: single person] households are a growing family form. They compared two years – 2006 when 23% of households were that type, and 2021 by which time they are expected to grow to 26%. A lot of single-person households are made up of older people who may have lost their partner. Like most countries in the developed world, New Zealand's ageing population is growing, as people continue to live longer, so this type of living situation is expected to rise.
Speaker 2 Yeah, I suppose that's true. So what else did they say?
Speaker 1 They said that currently just under 40% of households were couples with at least one dependent child and around [Q25: 20]% of households are made up of couples without children. Childless households are expected to increase much faster than couples with children over the next few decades. Of course, people who have children are more often deciding to have smaller families and are putting parenthood off until later in life. In 2007, the average age of women giving birth to their first child was 28 years; I think it's risen to around 30 years now.
Speaker 2 I suppose a lot of people want to get their career established, maybe buy a house, those sorts of things first, don't they?
Speaker 1 Yes, that's true. [Q26: Younger people] nowadays also appreciate a few years of freedom with no family commitments. People now have more mobility – with people going overseas for extended periods for work and travel. If you already have children, it's difficult to have those experiences.
Speaker 2 Wow – just think what it will be like when our generation gets old. With more people choosing not to have kids, getting married later and concentrating on their careers, there's going to be more elderly people with no one to support them. I mean, traditionally, families looked after the elderly members in their homes, but even now [Q27: an increasing number] of people are spending their old age in a retirement home because either the family is spread geographically or their children work so much they aren't able to give them the time they need. Did the programme suggest that relationships and families are becoming less important to people in general?
Speaker 1 No, they indicated that the decline of the traditional family structure was more about social acceptance of other forms and people taking advantage of the increasing number of choices. Although at the end of the programme they started talking about how technology has had an adverse effect on traditional families. People are becoming more materialistic, but more importantly we are becoming less sociable. [Q28–30: The feeling of community] is disappearing, because people are using texts, email and social media to interact with others rather than talking.
Speaker 2 Well, that's not really a new point of view, is it? People have been talking about that for years. Anyway, I don't agree. I visit my parents the first weekend of every month, but in-between times I keep in touch by e-mail.
Speaker 1 Why not by telephone?
Speaker 2 Well, it's cheaper to use the Internet and it's much quicker.
Speaker 1 Hmm, I don't think that's such a good idea. I prefer to be able to speak directly to people.…. (fade out)

Section 4 In today's lecture we will look at factors that affect the election process. An election is a formal decision-making process by which a population chooses a representative to take on a specific responsibility. Elections have been operated in modern democratic societies since the 17th century. Six types of elections are held in the United Kingdom. These are: General elections to appoint National Government, European Parliament elections, local elections to appoint Local Government, Mayoral elections and Police and Crime Commissioner elections. Unlike other types, General elections do not have (31) [Q1: fixed dates]; though in the UK the political party in power is required to call an election at least every five years. Anyone who lives in the UK, is aged 18 or over on polling day and who is a national of the United Kingdom, the Republic of Ireland, a Commonwealth country, Cyprus or a European Union member state can apply to be included in the UK Electoral Register. Convicted persons detained in prison or a mental hospital or a person who has ever been found guilty of certain illegal practices (such as corruption) are not [Q2: eligible] to vote. We'll now move on to 'voter turnout' - this is the percentage of (32) eligible voters who cast a ballot in an election. One of the strongest factors affecting voter turnout is whether voting is compulsory. In [Q3: Australia], for example, voter registration and attendance at a polling booth have been mandatory since the 1920s. Since Australia typically has around 10% of eligible voters who are not registered to vote and around 6% of invalid votes, actual voter turnouts in Australia are usually (33) close to 81%. In countries where voting is not compulsory, many members of the population who are entitled to vote, do not exercise their rights and do not go to polling stations on election day. Numerous reports from various countries around the world suggest that fewer voters are turning out for elections than in the past. This falling trend has been significant in the United States, Western Europe, Japan and (34) [Q4: Latin America]. For example, the percentage of Americans eligible to vote who did, in fact, vote was 63% in 1960, but this percentage has been falling ever since. Voter turnout in 2008 was 62% - the only year since the 1960s when a similar turnout was achieved. Research shows that socioeconomic factors significantly affect whether or not individuals develop the habit of voting. The most important socioeconomic factor affecting voter turnout is education. The more educated a person is, the more likely he or she is to vote. (35 or 36) Income appears to have some independent effect too, as studies show that richer people are more likely to vote than poor people, regardless of their educational background. Young people are far less likely to vote than older generations, and (35 or 36) single people are less likely to vote than married people. 'Voter apathy' (lack of caring) poses a huge problem for parties and individuals reliant on their supporters casting a ballot on election day. Overall, voter apathy is lower in national government elections than other types of elections, but a number of specific factors have been identified as important influences on voter apathy. These include how the voter sees the parties, the candidates, and the importance of the issues in an election. In terms of how voters see the parties and candidates up for election, lack of trust or a feeling that nothing will change regardless of who wins the election are opinions that can increase voter apathy. Why bother if all parties are corrupt and nothing gets better anyway? It is therefore important for leaders and parties to inspire (37) [Q7: confidence] so that more voters will turn out to give them their backing. In theory, another factor that is likely to increase turnout is a 'close race' – where election outcome could easily go either way. In elections where it seems clear that one party or candidate will win, voter apathy may increase as people think why bother if the outcome is inevitable. This can actually be a huge concern for the favoured candidate or party, as if their supporters do not turn out on election day, their competitor can achieve an unexpected win. The perceived importance of issues in an election also influences voter turnout and increases or decreases voter apathy in the following ways. If the issues in an election are not of (38) [Q8: personal importance] to a voter, their apathy may be increased. For example, an election campaign focussed on improving the circumstances of families may not be of interest to individuals without children. Conversely, if an election campaign focuses on topics that will affect an individual's life, they are more likely to vote. Voter fatigue (tiredness) is also a form of voter apathy which occurs when voters are expected to vote too often. For instance, this happened in Canada when voters were asked to vote in a federal election three times in five years (2004, 2006, 2008) and at each election voter turnout significantly decreased. Other practical issues also affect voter turnout. For example, (39) [Q9: bad weather] can reduce turnouts. How easy it is to vote is also a concern. In many states in America and most Latin American nations, voters must go through separate voter registration procedures before they are allowed to vote. This two-step process quite clearly appears to decrease turnout as U.S. states with no, or easier, registration requirements consistently have larger turnouts. The final issue relating to collecting valid votes that I will discuss today is known as 'ballot fatigue'. Many people are simply very lazy when it comes to voting so they may just pick the first candidates they see on the ballot just to get it over with. In a case of ballot fatigue it would therefore follow that the farther down the candidate list a candidate is, the fewer the number of votes they will collect. The ballot fatigue principle suggests that affected voters use up all their patience and/or their (40) [Q10: knowledge] as they work their way down the ballot and make an 'easy' choice to get the process over. Possible methods of improving voting processes focus on making voting easier; for example, making ballot papers more user-friendly; increasing the number of possible voting locations; lowering the average time voters have to spend waiting in line; or encouraging companies to give workers some time off on voting day.
